abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Lessons from
            implementation of the project are suggested as follows.
            Transferring governance authority to water user associations
            improves water allocation decisions, the prioritization of
            maintenance works, and the design and quality of
            construction, suggesting user-focused financial
            arrangements, where irrigation fees are collected from, and
            managed by farmers, are the key to long-run financial
            sustainability and accountability. In addition, long-term
            commitment to reform agenda, where components with continued
            government support is crucial, there is the need to devise
            modes of engagement to keep government policy on agreed
            trajectories, especially in the face of short-term
            considerations. More realistic assessments of the risk of
            loss of political momentum need to be factored into project
            design. Recently issued government regulations and
            ministerial decrees, provide a more credible framework for
            the design of medium- to long-term intervention strategies.
            Effective water resources management is best undertaken
            within a river basin framework that: (a) takes account of
            all water users ensuring efficient allocation; (b)
            integrates irrigation development with land-use planning;
            (c) pays attention to environmental aspects of water use,
            including up-stream water management and water quality; and,
            (d) undertakes integrated reform of government and farmer
            irrigation institutions. Project experience shows that
            ensuring success of this process of inter-connected reforms,
            requires adequate ground work at the design stage, and
            adherence to the required sequence of reforms during the
            implementation stage. Other lessons suggest launching
            scaled-up versions of pilot, or small-scale schemes, and,
            projects which involve physical investments as well as
            policy, process and institutional reforms, the nature of
            outcome/output should be better defined, with quantitative
            indicators tied to objectives, and a monitoring and
            evaluation program that includes a base-line survey, and
            independent qualitative assessments of major outputs during
            implementation, and on completion.
